etymologies: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘intone a song’): from Latin modulat- ‘measured, made melody’, from the verb modulari, from modulus ‘measure’ (see modulus)

definitions: exert a modifying or controlling influence on

examples.text: the state attempts to modulate private business's cash flow

definitions: vary the strength, tone, or pitch of (one's voice)

examples.text: we all modulate our voice by hearing it

definitions: alter the amplitude or frequency of (an electromagnetic wave or other oscillation) in accordance with the variations of a second signal, typically one of a lower frequency

examples.text: radio waves are modulated to carry the analog information of the voice

shortDefinitions: alter electromagnetic wave in accordance with second signal

definitions: change from one key to another

examples.text: the first half of the melody, modulating from E minor to G

definitions: change from one form or condition into (another)

examples.text: ideals and opinions are not modulated into authoritative journalese

shortDefinitions: change to another form or condition
